However, Parliament Speaker Nabih Berri reaffirmed Lebanon‚Äôs commitment to Resolution 1701, with no amendments. Berri made clear that Lebanon stands united on Resolution 1701, and that 'Israel' must respect it. He anticipated that Hochstein would push Israel‚Äôs maximum demands but remained confident that nothing could be imposed on Lebanon. Hochstein‚Äôs visit, it seems, was primarily a test of Lebanon‚Äôs resolve‚Äîan attempt to gauge whether the country, particularly the resistance, might offer concessions under pressure. But Lebanon‚Äôs leadership, backed by its steadfast resistance, will not yield. Neither the US, nor the Zionist entity, nor their allies can force Lebanon into submission. Those following the situation behind the scenes of Hochstein‚Äôs visit might believe 'Israel' can impose its will, but the facts tell a different story. For over three weeks, it has faced setbacks along the border with Lebanon, failing to make significant gains or take control of any Lebanese towns. These developments underscore that the US-Israeli pressure campaign is shallow and ineffective against the united front of Lebanon, its resistance, and its people. Ultimately, the outcome of this conflict will be decided on the battlefield, where the resistance, as emphasized by its leader, Sayyed Hasan Nasrallah (may he rest in peace), continues to hold the upper hand.
